Nitrogen_Deficiency.name: Nitrogen Deficiency
Nitrogen_Deficiency.description: Nitrogen deficiency causes yellowing of older leaves starting from the tips, stunted growth, and pale green to yellow color in plants.
visual_symptoms: Pale green to yellow color overall
Leaves turn light green first, then yellow

severity_indicators.mild: Light green color in lower leaves
severity_indicators.severe: Entire plant pale yellow, severe stunting

immediate: Apply foliar spray with liquid nitrogen

chemical.name: Urea (46-0-0)
chemical.timing: Split application - 1/3 at planting, 1/3 at 30 days, 1/3 at 60 days
chemical.precautions: Avoid over-application. Can cause leaf burn if applied to wet foliage.

organic.name: Blood meal or Composted manure
organic.precautions: Well-composted material preferred to avoid nitrogen tie-up.

prevention: Avoid excessive irrigation that leaches nitrogen

Phosphorus_Deficiency.name: Phosphorus Deficiency
Phosphorus_Deficiency.description: Phosphorus deficiency causes dark green or purplish discoloration of leaves, especially in cool weather, with stunted root development.
visual_symptoms: Purple coloring on leaf undersides and stems

severity_indicators.severe: Intense purple/brown leaves, severe stunting, poor yield

immediate: Use foliar spray with phosphoric acid solution
Add bone meal or rock phosphate
long_term: Adjust soil pH (6.0-7.0 optimal for P availability)

chemical.name: DAP (Diammonium Phosphate 18-46-0)
chemical.application_method: Band application near roots at planting
chemical.timing: At planting or early growth stage
chemical.precautions: Avoid direct seed contact. May cause ammonia toxicity if over-applied.

organic.name: Rock Phosphate or Bone Meal
organic.precautions: Slow release - best applied season before planting.

prevention: Avoid excessive zinc or iron in soil

Potassium_Deficiency.name: Potassium Deficiency
Potassium_Deficiency.description: Potassium deficiency causes yellowing and browning of leaf margins and tips, with weak stems and poor fruit quality.
visual_symptoms: Browning and scorching of leaf tips and margins

severity_indicators.severe: Severe necrosis, leaf death, poor fruit quality

immediate: Apply potassium sulfate or muriate of potash
Use foliar spray with potassium nitrate
long_term: Avoid excessive calcium that blocks K uptake

chemical.name: Muriate of Potash (KCl 0-0-60)
chemical.timing: Before planting and during fruit development
chemical.precautions: High salt index - avoid excessive use on sensitive crops.

organic.name: Wood ash or Greensand
organic.precautions: Wood ash raises soil pH - monitor pH levels.

prevention: Regular soil testing for potassium levels
Balance calcium and magnesium with potassium
Mulch to conserve soil moisture and nutrients

Magnesium_Deficiency.name: Magnesium Deficiency
Magnesium_Deficiency.description: Magnesium deficiency causes interveinal chlorosis (yellowing between leaf veins) in older leaves while veins remain green.
visual_symptoms: Red or purple tints may develop

severity_indicators.mild: Light interveinal yellowing on older leaves
severity_indicators.moderate: Distinct yellow patterns, some leaf curling

immediate: Apply Epsom salt (magnesium sulfate) as foliar spray
long_term: Balance potassium levels (high K blocks Mg)

chemical.name: Epsom Salt (Magnesium Sulfate)
chemical.application_method: Foliar spray (2-3% solution) or soil application
chemical.timing: During active growth, repeat every 2-3 weeks
chemical.precautions: Do not apply in hot weather. Rinse equipment after use.

organic.name: Dolomitic Limestone
organic.precautions: Slowly available - plan ahead. May raise soil pH.

Iron_Deficiency.name: Iron Deficiency (Chlorosis)
Iron_Deficiency.description: Iron deficiency causes interveinal chlorosis in young leaves, with severe yellowing while veins remain green.
visual_symptoms: White or bleached appearance in severe cases

severity_indicators.severe: White or bleached leaves, stunted growth

immediate: Apply chelated iron (Fe-EDTA or Fe-EDDHA) as foliar spray
Lower soil pH if too alkaline

chemical.name: Chelated Iron (Fe-EDDHA 6%)
chemical.application_method: Foliar spray (0.5% solution) or soil drench
chemical.timing: During active growth, repeat every 2-3 weeks
chemical.precautions: Avoid mixing with phosphorus fertilizers. Use separate applications.

organic.name: Iron Sulfate (Ferrous Sulfate)
organic.precautions: Acidifies soil - monitor pH. May stain surfaces.

prevention: Maintain proper soil pH (acidic for iron availability)

Calcium_Deficiency.name: Calcium Deficiency
Calcium_Deficiency.description: Calcium deficiency causes tip burn, blossom end rot in fruits, and death of growing points.
visual_symptoms: Death of terminal buds and young leaves
Blossom end rot in tomatoes and peppers

severity_indicators.mild: Slight tip burn on young leaves
severity_indicators.moderate: Blossom end rot appearing on fruits
severity_indicators.severe: Death of growing points, severe fruit damage

immediate: Apply calcium nitrate as foliar spray
long_term: Incorporate lime or gypsum before planting

chemical.name: Calcium Nitrate (Ca(NO3)2)
chemical.precautions: Do not mix with sulfate or phosphate fertilizers.

organic.name: Gypsum (Calcium Sulfate)
organic.precautions: Does not raise pH - safe for neutral soils.

Sulfur_Deficiency.name: Sulfur Deficiency
Sulfur_Deficiency.description: Sulfur deficiency causes overall yellowing similar to nitrogen deficiency, but affects younger leaves first.
visual_symptoms: Pale green to yellow color overall
Similar to nitrogen deficiency but starts in new growth

severity_indicators.severe: Severe chlorosis, stunted plants, poor yield

immediate: Apply ammonium sulfate or potassium sulfate

chemical.name: Ammonium Sulfate (21-0-0-24S)
chemical.timing: At planting and during active growth
chemical.precautions: Acidifies soil over time. Monitor soil pH.

organic.name: Elemental Sulfur
organic.precautions: Slowly available - oxidizes to sulfate in soil.

prevention: Regular soil testing for sulfur levels

Zinc_Deficiency.name: Zinc Deficiency
Zinc_Deficiency.description: Zinc deficiency causes interveinal chlorosis, stunted growth, and small leaves (little leaf).

severity_indicators.severe: Severe stunting, white bud, poor yield

immediate: Apply zinc sulfate as foliar spray

chemical.name: Zinc Sulfate (ZnSO4Â·7H2O)
chemical.application_method: Foliar spray (0.5% solution) or soil application
chemical.timing: During early growth, repeat if needed
chemical.precautions: Avoid mixing with alkaline materials. May cause phytotoxicity at high rates.

prevention: Avoid high phosphorus levels that tie up zinc

Boron_Deficiency.name: Boron Deficiency
Boron_Deficiency.description: Boron deficiency causes death of growing points, hollow stems, and corky tissues in fruits.

severity_indicators.severe: Complete death of growing points, no fruiting

immediate: Apply borax or boric acid as foliar spray
long_term: Regular soil testing (boron is easily leached)

chemical.name: Borax (11.3% B)
chemical.application_method: Foliar spray (0.1% solution) or soil application
chemical.precautions: CAUTION: Narrow margin between deficiency and toxicity. Do not exceed recommended rates.

organic.name: Solubor or Boric Acid
organic.application_method: Dilute foliar spray or soil application
organic.precautions: Very narrow safe range - careful measurement required.

Manganese_Deficiency.name: Manganese Deficiency
Manganese_Deficiency.description: Manganese deficiency causes interveinal chlorosis and necrotic spots on young leaves.
visual_symptoms: Affects middle to younger leaves first

severity_indicators.severe: Severe necrosis, stunted plants, poor yield

immediate: Apply manganese sulfate as foliar spray
long_term: Lower soil pH if too alkaline

chemical.name: Manganese Sulfate (MnSO4)
chemical.application_method: Foliar spray (0.5% solution) or soil application
chemical.timing: During active growth, repeat as needed
chemical.precautions: Most effective as foliar spray. Avoid excessive rates.

organic.name: Chelated Manganese (Mn-EDTA)
organic.precautions: More expensive but more efficient than sulfate forms.
